coredata.dc:title: Development of a Ct equation taking into consideration the effect of lot variability on the inactivation of Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts with ozone
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Sivaganesan, Mano
Mariñas, Benito J.
coredata.dc:description:
Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts are prevalent in surface water and ground water under the influence of surface water, and are difficult to inactivate using free chlorine, the most common disinfectant currently used for treating drinking water. In contrast, it has been shown that ozone is a more effective disinfectant than chlorine. US EPA is currently evaluating a treatment rule, which addresses the control of C. parvum oocysts in drinking water. The use of Ct (average disinfectant concentration multiplied by characteristic contact time) values is being considered as one of the options for demonstrating adequate control of this microbial contaminant. The purpose of this study is to incorporate the variability in inactivation kinetics among different lots of oocysts and to develop a statistical model for
Ct
based on first-order delayed Chick–Watson inactivation kinetics. A Bayesian approach is used to estimate the delayed Chick–Watson kinetic parameters. A log-linear regression analysis is then used to represent the effect of temperature on the resulting kinetic parameters. The overall model developed in this study provides an approach for water utilities and regulatory agencies to decide on the level of safety needed when developing treatment requirements for the inactivation of C. parvum oocysts with ozone as part of broader risk assessment considerations.

head.ce:title: Development of a Ct equation taking into consideration the effect of lot variability on the inactivation of Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts with ozone

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Water Supply and Water Resources Division, National Risk Management Research Laboratory, US Environmental Protection Agency, 26 W. Martin Luther King Drive, Cincinnati, OH 45268, USA

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL 61801, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts are prevalent in surface water and ground water under the influence of surface water, and are difficult to inactivate using free chlorine, the most common disinfectant currently used for treating drinking water. In contrast, it has been shown that ozone is a more effective disinfectant than chlorine. US EPA is currently evaluating a treatment rule, which addresses the control of C. parvum oocysts in drinking water. The use of Ct (average disinfectant concentration multiplied by characteristic contact time) values is being considered as one of the options for demonstrating adequate control of this microbial contaminant. The purpose of this study is to incorporate the variability in inactivation kinetics among different lots of oocysts and to develop a statistical model for
Ct
based on first-order delayed Chick–Watson inactivation kinetics. A Bayesian approach is used to estimate the delayed Chick–Watson kinetic parameters. A log-linear regression analysis is then used to represent the effect of temperature on the resulting kinetic parameters. The overall model developed in this study provides an approach for water utilities and regulatory agencies to decide on the level of safety needed when developing treatment requirements for the inactivation of C. parvum oocysts with ozone as part of broader risk assessment considerations.

ce:section.ce:para:
Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts are microbial contaminants prevalent in surface water, as well as in ground water under the influence of surface water, that are difficult to inactivate with free and combined chlorine, the most common drinking water disinfectants currently in use throughout the world. In contrast, ozone has been shown to be a more effective disinfectant for controlling this protozoan parasite. Accordingly, the US Environmental Protection Agency is currently evaluating new minimum
Ct
(i.e., the product of average disinfectant concentration and characteristic contact time) requirements for the control of C. parvum oocysts with ozone. Inactivation data analyses (Clark et al., 2002, 2003; Rosen et al., 2002; Sivaganesan et al., 2003) performed in support of these efforts have been based on the recently demonstrated validity of the
Ct
concept for C. parvum oocyst inactivation (Rennecker et al., 2001). The
Ct
concept states that the inactivation efficiency achieved at a certain
Ct
is independent of the concentration of the disinfectant, ozone in the present case, used. Clark et al. (2002) and Rosen et al. (2002) performed statistical analyses with a limited number of data sets (Rennecker et al., 1999; Li et al., 2000; Oppenheimer et al., 2000; Owens et al., 2000), and although their approach was consistent with the
Ct
concept, they did not take into consideration the occurrence of an initial lag phase
Ct
(i.e.,
C
t
lag
) during which little or no inactivation takes place. However, recent studies (Rennecker et al., 2000, 2001; Driedger et al., 2001; Hirata et al., 2001; Corona-Vasquez et al., 2002; Rochelle et al., 2002) have shown that the inactivation kinetics of C. parvum oocysts with ozone is typically characterized by an initial lag phase followed by post-lag phase of pseudo-first-order inactivation, consistent with the delayed Chick–Watson kinetic model (Wickramanayake and Sproul, 1988). Both of these phases have been found to be consistent with the
Ct
concept (Rennecker et al., 2001).

Sivaganesan et al. (2003) reanalyzed the data of Rennecker et al. (1999) using a Bayesian approach to determine the extent of the lag phase and the rate constant for the post-lag phase of inactivation with the aid of a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) computational method (Brooks, 1998; Gelfand and Smith, 1990; Gelman et al., 1995). However, a comparison of the various data sets now available in the literature (Rennecker et al., 1999, 2000, 2001; Hirata et al., 2001; Li et al., 2000; Driedger et al., 2001; Corona-Vasquez et al., 2002) for the inactivation of C. parvum oocysts with ozone have revealed that both the lag phase
Ct
and the post-lag phase inactivation rate vary from oocyst lot to oocyst lot even when using the same strain of C. parvum, and when following the same oocyst propagation, stock preparation and viability methods. Consequently, there is a need to characterize this variability and to assess the necessity of taking it into consideration when developing Ct requirements.

The main goal of this study is to develop a Ct equation incorporating the effect of variability among different lots of C. parvum oocysts in the inactivation kinetics of this microbial contaminant with ozone. Data sets reported in the literature are first analyzed with a Bayesian approach (Sivaganesan et al., 2003) with the goal of estimating the lag phase
Ct
, and the post-lag phase rate constant. Two separate mixed linear models are subsequently used to characterize the effects of pH, temperature (
T
), viability method and oocyst lot on the lag phase
Ct
and the post-lag phase inactivation rate constant.

The data sets analyzed in this study and their corresponding experimental conditions are summarized in Table 1 . Rennecker et al. (1999, 2000, 2001), Driedger et al. (2001), and Corona-Vasquez et al. (2002) performed the experiments with buffered synthetic solutions in a semi-batch reactor, and determined oocyst viability by a modified in vitro excystation method. Hirata et al. (2001) also performed their experiments with buffered synthetic solutions and using a semi-batch reactor, but they used split samples to determine oocyst viability by both modified in vitro excystation and animal infectivity assays. The data reported by Li et al. (2000) was obtained with buffered synthetic solutions in a batch reactor, and the viability of the oocysts was determined by an animal infectivity method. The experiments by Rochelle et al. (2002) were performed with unspecified water in a semi-batch reactor, and the oocyst viability was determined by cell culture/RT-PCR assay. An additional factor that might affect inactivation kinetics is the strain of C. parvum used. Unfortunately, except for the work by Hirata et al. (2001), all other studies have been performed with oocysts of the Iowa strain and thus such effect could not be presently assessed.

As part of the Bayesian analysis, prior knowledge of the state of nature is presented by specifying a prior distribution. A diffuse normal prior with mean 0 and variance 106 is used for

2
(which covers the range of data variance) to evaluate the robustness of the results. No apparent difference was seen in the posterior distributions of the model parameters.

Values for the parameters

The data for the inactivation kinetics of C. parvum oocysts with ozone presented by Driedger et al. (2001), Hirata et al. (2001), Rennecker et al. (1999, 2000, 2001), Corona-Vasquez et al. (2002), as well as the results by Li et al. (2000) for which these authors provided oocyst lot information are used to estimate

Data sets for which oocyst viability was determined by the modified in vitro excystation method but without correcting for the viability of the control were corrected accordingly so that

ce:section.ce:section-title: Estimating a safety factor for Ct
ce:section.ce:para:
The variations associated with different random effects could be taken into account by including a safety factor in predicting future
Ct
values. There are three components to the total error variance:
(a)
variance associated with the mean estimate,
(b)
variance associated with different oocyst lots,
(c)
variance associated with the effects of any remaining variables such as experimental and analytical variability.

A certain combination of these three components could be used to calculate a safety factor for
Ct
. Using only (a) means that only the error associated with the mean estimate is included in the safety factor, and that consequently the error associated with the lots or any other variables are disregarded. Incorporating (a) and (b) gives a safety factor which accounts for the error associated with the mean estimate and the variation among different oocyst lots. Adding all three components gives a safety factor for a future
Ct
. The use of such a safety factor can provide guidance to drinking water utilities. Lot variability is accounted for in the current Long Term 2 Enhanced Surface Water Treatment Rule (LT2 Rule) to inactivate C. parvum oocysts with ozone. Thus a water treatment plant may want to use a similar safety factor. Another reason to use the above safety factor may be to reduce the operating cost of the treatment plant. The upper bound for the
Ct
model given by Eq. (1) is developed by letting the estimated standard error (SE) of
ln
(
k
^

For a given mean log inactivation
μ
and temperature

Note that in Eq. (18),

and

are calculated by Eqs. (A.3) or (A.4) or (A.5) presented in the Appendix A.

The Li et al. (2000) data for which lot information was not specified and the cell culture data from Rochelle et al. (2002) are used to validate the model developed in this study. Eqs. (19) and (20) were applied to obtain the predicted inactivation curves and corresponding 90% confidence bounds at 1, 10 and 22°C. The resulting predicted curves are compared to 1°C data sets from Li et al. (2000) and Rochelle et al. (2002) in Fig. 3 , and to 10 and 22°C data sets from Li et al. (2000) in Figs. 4 and 5
, respectively. All the data in Figs. 3 and 4 fall within the safety factor which incorporates the lot variability. Greater data scatter due to analytical variability and lot variability is seen in Fig. 5. Only fourteen of the twenty four data points are within the upper confidence limit which includes the lot variability.

Bayesian analysis has been used to estimate the lag phase
Ct
and post-lag phase rate constant
k
for a delayed Chick–Watson regression model. Monte Carlo samples from the posterior distributions are used to estimate these parameters. A log-linear mixed model is then used to model the estimated post-lag phase rate constants and lag phase
Ct
values as functions of the fixed factor temperature and the random factor oocyst lot. A formula is developed to estimate the minimum
Ct
requirement for a given mean log inactivation level of C. parvum oocysts. Thus, by using this two-step procedure one can estimate the minimum required
Ct
which includes a safety factor, instead of estimating a single estimate for
Ct
.

The present findings suggest that the model developed in this paper can be used to estimate the lag phase
Ct
, post-lag phase rate constant, and minimum
Ct
requirement with confidence intervals for a given temperature and target survival ratio of C. parvum oocysts.

The model developed in this study presents a two-step approach for water utilities and regulatory agencies to decide on the level of safety needed when developing treatment requirements for the inactivation of C. parvum oocysts with ozone as part of a comprehensive risk analysis incorporating other factors such as the occurrence of oocysts in raw waters, fate of the parasite in other water treatment processes part of multi-barrier systems, epidemiological information, and overall cost analysis.
